title: Acute Decompensated Heart Failure National Registry (ADHERE) Algorithm
description: Predicts in-hospital mortality in patients hospitalized with acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF). This is a simple decision tree algorithm that uses three readily available clinical parameters to risk-stratify heart failure patients.

parameters.name: bun
parameters.description: Blood urea nitrogen level at admission

parameters.name: systolic_bp
parameters.description: Systolic blood pressure at admission (only assessed when BUN ≥43 mg/dL)

parameters.name: creatinine
parameters.description: Serum creatinine level at admission (only assessed when BUN ≥43 mg/dL and SBP <115 mmHg)

result.name: mortality_risk
result.description: In-hospital mortality risk category based on ADHERE algorithm

ranges.interpretation: Low risk of in-hospital mortality (2.1-2.3%). Standard heart failure management on general medical ward is appropriate. Monitor response to therapy and optimize guideline-directed medical therapy.
Intermediate risk of in-hospital mortality (5.5-6.4%). Consider enhanced monitoring on telemetry unit. May benefit from more intensive diuretic therapy and closer hemodynamic monitoring.

ranges.description: BUN ≥43 mg/dL, SBP <115 mmHg, and creatinine <2.75 mg/dL
ranges.interpretation: Intermediate-high risk of in-hospital mortality (12.4-12.8%). Consider intensive care unit monitoring or step-down unit care. May require inotropic support and aggressive hemodynamic optimization.

ranges.description: BUN ≥43 mg/dL, SBP <115 mmHg, and creatinine ≥2.75 mg/dL
ranges.interpretation: High risk of in-hospital mortality (19.8-21.9%). Strong consideration for intensive care unit admission. Likely requires inotropic support, aggressive diuresis, and consideration of advanced heart failure therapies or mechanical circulatory support.

references: Fonarow GC, Adams KF Jr, Abraham WT, Yancy CW, Boscardin WJ; ADHERE Scientific Advisory Committee. Risk stratification for in-hospital mortality in acutely decompensated heart failure: classification and regression tree analysis. JAMA. 2005 Feb 2;293(5):572-80. doi: 10.1001/jama.293.5.572.

Abraham WT, Fonarow GC, Albert NM, et al. Predictors of in-hospital mortality in patients hospitalized for heart failure: insights from the Organized Program to Initiate Lifesaving Treatment in Hospitalized Patients with Heart Failure (OPTIMIZE-HF). J Am Coll Cardiol. 2008 Jul 29;52(5):347-56. doi: 10.1016/j.jacc.2008.04.028.
formula: Decision tree algorithm: If BUN <43 mg/dL → Low Risk. If BUN ≥43 mg/dL and SBP ≥115 mmHg → Intermediate Risk. If BUN ≥43 mg/dL, SBP <115 mmHg, and creatinine <2.75 mg/dL → Intermediate-High Risk. If BUN ≥43 mg/dL, SBP <115 mmHg, and creatinine ≥2.75 mg/dL → High Risk.
notes: This algorithm was derived from the ADHERE registry, which included over 65,000 hospitalizations for heart failure
The algorithm uses a simple decision tree approach rather than a point-based scoring system
BUN was the strongest single predictor of in-hospital mortality in the ADHERE registry
The algorithm should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment and other prognostic factors
Not validated in patients with acute heart failure secondary to acute coronary syndromes
May not be applicable to patients with end-stage renal disease or those on dialysis
The mortality percentages are based on the original ADHERE registry population and may vary in different populations
